This recent poll that shows widespread support for the Arizona law even as the press complains about how unpopular it is illustrates a point.

Hillary Clinton had a commanding lead among Democratic Primary voters until she muffed the question about driver's licenses for illegals. Then her lead disappeared. There was never another controversial question asked during the Democratic Primary debates. She lost support amning DEMOCRATIC primary voters. Many in the Democratic base are worried about the effect of unconstrained immigration on wages and the economy. As Paul Krugman recently noted in his blog: "open immigration can’t coexist with a strong social safety net." That is among Democrats. It's not only Rebublicans and Independents who are concerned about illegal immigration, although Democrats are more likely to be intimidated by the threat of being called "racists." The press has been misrepresenting the politics of this.

There are basically four groups that support an open immigration policy in the middle of a severe recession:

Latinos

The Chamber of Commerce

The Leadership of the Democratic Party (but not the rank-and-file)

Journalists

What do I think of the law?  Let's see.  SB 1070 was written by State Senator Russell Pearce's outsourced legal arm ILRI (Immigration Law Reform Institute) which is affiliated with FAIR (Federation of American Immigration Reform) which the Southern Poverty Law Center described as "racist and dangerous".   But racist affiliations don't end there.   FAIR received $1.3 million from Pioneer Fund a, "white supremacist foundation that specializes in funding 'science' dedicated to demonstrating white intellectual and moral superiority."   The racist law effectively declares (cultural) war on the fastest growing minority group in the country, legal and illegal, and only a newly formed, vast political coalition of U.S. minority civic and business groups can respond and rebuke this declaration with equal or more vigor and provide advocacy and protection against threatened quality of life issues for all U.S. minority citizens.

Immigration reform is sorely needed in the U.S. Without question the first step that must happen is to secure our borders to the north AND south. The US-Canada border is the single largest border between 2 countries in the world. It is also the most porous border in the US and a favorite of terrorists including the 9/11 terrorists. The border to the south is THE major route for drugs into the U.S. and has become so crime ridden, border towns are being taken over.

No law that any state or county has passed in recent years will do anything to address illegal immigration until the borders are secured and we know who and what is coming into and leaving the country. Laws such as that passed in AZ will only alienate and discriminate. Of course many white people don't see what the big deal is. They are never the targets of racial profiling or 'random' screening. They would certainly feel different if they became regularly profiled. Unless and until we secure the borders, this illegal immigration issue will be cyclic, recurring every 20-30 years or so.

All these exhortations to "read the bill" are empty attempts to undermine the credibility of people who are expressing a legitimate concern.

Laws are not enforced in a vacuum. Reading the bill (as many who have posted on this topic for and against it surely have) will not magically tell you everything you need to know about how a law will be enforced.

"Reasonable suspicion" is not an undefinable term, but it IS based on context. The reason this is a bill that will result in racial profiling is that you are giving local law enforcement the power to detain suspects on the basis of race.

Those who defend the bill defend it on the grounds that race cannot be the "sole" criteria. This is true, but there is absolutely NO guidance as to what other "reasonable" criteria may be used. And the fact that the bill allows race to be taken into account means exactly what it sounds like for those who are "reading the bill": race can be a factor in developing reasonable suspicion.

Thus, if I am a local officer and I think that most illegals I have encountered wear cheap looking jeans, this, combined with the fact that the person is Latino, could be the basis for the officer to ask for a person's papers. I will have to justify my suspicion in court, but if a (also local, and probably up for reelection by a mostly white electorate) judge who is also concerned about illegal immigration defers to my judgment as a local officer, I will have passed the reasonable suspicion test.

Take this example and combine it with any number of factors including type of car being driven, type of hairstyle, certain smell, place where "illegals" typically hang out, and you have the makings of a race based police state.

This is what people are concerned about.

If your response is, well, most illegal immigrants are Latino, why yes, that is true, but another thing that is true is that even in Arizona, the VAST MAJORITY of Latinos are U.S. citizens or legal immigrants. Race is NOT a proxy for illegal immigration, and you will end up harassing a significant number of persons who have no right to be harassed other than because of the way they look. If this is Equal Protection under the laws (for all you Tea Partiers out there, it's the 14th Amendment), then maybe I don't understand the Constitution.

I also have been blogging about my daughter's unremitting, unrelenting disease of drug addiction and our parenting of her daughter, our three-year-old granddaughter. I also hit the moment of truth several Sundays ago, when our daughter was taken by ambulance to the local hospital's ICU for her drug overdose. She lived, and we had to choreograph with the bail bondswoman to ensure she was returned to jail, which is the only way to save her life. Jail is the only place where she will be safe. I also find it scary writing about this personal problem, but addiction is a public health problem that needs to transform into public policy, because there are millions of addicted people out there and more millions who have been directly or indirectly affected -- and there is no way all of us are bad parents who caused this awful disease.

I support you in every way. I hope that you and I and all the other millions of us can shed a light on this terrible problem that is taking too many of a whole generation of young people.

My public story is at spittingrits.blogspot.com.

The last 40 years of the offshore oil drilling safety record is being held up by defenders as being something remarkable. How absolutely absurd.

Would one argue that nuclear energy is safe since there has been only one bad accident--Chernobyl. Then go further to ignore the damage caused by the infrastructure, waste and other side effects of the industry.

The problem is one of scale. With Chernobyl, tens of thousands suffered and an entire region was laid to waste. Oil is no different. One rig, one blow out and the effects appear likely to be widespread, immediate and long term.

The question is: How willing are we to allow the occasional mass disaster to destroy entire economies, a way of life for tens of thousands of people? What is revealing, disturbing is how casual so many Americans are that fellow citizens are conveniently expendable and that an ecosystem destroyed is just the cost of living.

If I lived on the Gulf Coast, I'm not so sure that I could maintain a civil demeanor with any big oil apologist without having the urge to dunk them body complete into a 42 gallon brrl/oil.
